title: Forward-Inverse Generation for Low-Resource Domain-specific Event Detection
author: Tanmay Parekh (University of California, Los Angeles), Yuxuan Dong (University of California, Los Angeles), Lucas Bandarkar (University of California, Los Angeles), Artin Kim (University of California, Los Angeles), I-Hung Hsu (Google), Kai-Wei Chang (University of California, Los Angeles), Nanyun Peng (University of California, Los Angeles), ...
relevance_why: The paper presents a hybrid approach combining forward and inverse generation methods which could inspire novel audio generation techniques paralleling similar principles in audio processing tasks.
background: The task is to detect events from natural language without extensive labeled data, by generating synthetic data for training machine learning models.
contribution: This paper introduces Forward-Inverse Generation (FIG) to resolve issues in event detection by generating high-quality synthetic data, achieving better performance over existing methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods like forward and inverse generation either generated noisy labels or suffered from domain drift.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by integrating both generation strategies ensuring domain alignment and cleaner data.

key_innovation: Combines strengths of forward generation for trigger extraction and inverse generation for sentence creation, refining the generated data for better quality.
real_world_impact: Enhances event detection capabilities in low-resource settings, which can drastically improve the efficacy of applications in domains like medicine, law, and social media monitoring.
limitations: The approach assumes availability of unlabeled data, which may not be feasible in extremely specialized domains.

new_terms.Forward Generation: **Forward Generation** involves generating labels for existing data, enhancing unlabeled datasets for supervised learning.
new_terms.Inverse Generation: **Inverse Generation** generates data samples based on the labels, essentially attempting to create realistic data that conforms to the target labels.
